body.p: James P Martin was born in 1836 in Kentucky. He attended the U. S. Military Academy from July 1, 1855 to July 1, 1860. He served in Newport Barracks, Newport, Campbell County, Kentucky as a Second Lieutenant in the 7th Infantry and Fort Bragg, California as a First Lieutenant in the 7th Infantry. During the Civil War he was the Assistant Adjutant-General of Cavalry for the Army of the Potomac from January 10 to July 4 1862. Stationed in Washington D.C. January 10 to March 10 1862. Participated in the Peninsular Campaign March to August 1862. Became Acting Aide-de-Camp for Major-General McClellan from September to November of 1862, including the Battle of Antietam on September 17, 1862. Became Acting Aide-de-Camp for Major General Heintzelman in Washington D.C. from November 1862 to February 1863. Martin was promoted to Captain in the 7th Infantry on January 2, 1863. Acting Assistant Adjutants-General in the Discharge Office, Washington D.C. from February to May of 1863. In the Pennsylvania Campaign from June to July of 1863, participating in the Battle of Gettysburg July 2, 1863 and the pursuit in the aftermath. Acting Assistant Adjutant General of the 2nd Division, 5th Corps Army of the Potomac August 1863 to February 1864. While there, he participated in the suppression of the New York Draft Riots. As Acting Assistant Adjutant General of the Cavalry Bureau at Washington D.C. February 2, 1864 to October 1, 1866. Promoted to Bvt. Lieutenant Colonial on July 22, 1865.
